question.title: Apache HttpClient Multiple polling connections to server strategy

node.contents: I'm setting up a Java client for a server that I poll periodically and send messages to based on particular response. The strategy I used for the class is as follows:

astNode.text: I'm setting up a Java client for a server that I poll periodically and send messages to based on particular response. The strategy I used for the class is as follows:

elements.contents: public class PollingClient { private HttpClient client = getHttpClient(); // I get a DefaultHttpClient this way so it's easier to add connection manager and strategy etc to the client later private HttpPost httpPost = getHttpPost(); // same idea, I set headers there public String poll () { List<NameValuePair> formparams = new ArrayList<NameValuePair>(); formparams.add(new BasicNameValuePair("id", someId)); String responseString = null; try { UrlEncodedFormEntity formEntity = new UrlEncodedFormEntity(formparams, "UTF-8"); httppost.setURI(polluri)); httppost.setEntity(formEntity); HttpResponse response = httpclient.execute(httppost); HttpEntity entity = response.getEntity(); if (entity != null) { responseString = EntityUtils.toString(entity); } EntityUtils.consume(entity); } catch (Exception e) { e.printStackTrace(); } } public void send(String msg) { List<NameValuePair> formparams = new ArrayList<NameValuePair>(); formparams.add(new BasicNameValuePair("msg", msg)); formparams.add(new BasicNameValuePair("id", someId)); String responseString = null; try { UrlEncodedFormEntity formEntity = new UrlEncodedFormEntity(formparams, "UTF-8"); httppost.setURI(new URI(URL + "send")); httppost.setEntity(formEntity); HttpResponse response = httpclient.execute(httppost); HttpEntity entity = response.getEntity(); if (entity != null) { responseString = EntityUtils.toString(entity); } EntityUtils.consume(entity); } catch (Exception e) { e.printStackTrace(); } } }

comments.text: // I get a DefaultHttpClient this way so it's easier to add connection manager and strategy etc to the client later private HttpPost httpPost = getHttpPost(); // same idea, I set headers there public String poll () { List<NameValuePair> formparams = new ArrayList<NameValuePair>(); formparams.add(new BasicNameValuePair("id", someId)); String responseString = null; try { UrlEncodedFormEntity formEntity = new UrlEncodedFormEntity(formparams, "UTF-8"); httppost.setURI(polluri)); httppost.setEntity(formEntity); HttpResponse response = httpclient.execute(httppost); HttpEntity entity = response.getEntity(); if (entity != null) { responseString = EntityUtils.toString(entity); } EntityUtils.consume(entity); } catch (Exception e) { e.printStackTrace(); } } public void send(String msg) { List<NameValuePair> formparams = new ArrayList<NameValuePair>(); formparams.add(new BasicNameValuePair("msg", msg)); formparams.add(new BasicNameValuePair("id", someId)); String responseString = null; try { UrlEncodedFormEntity formEntity = new UrlEncodedFormEntity(formparams, "UTF-8"); httppost.setURI(new URI(URL + "send")); httppost.setEntity(formEntity); HttpResponse response = httpclient.execute(httppost); HttpEntity entity = response.getEntity(); if (entity != null) { responseString = EntityUtils.toString(entity); } EntityUtils.consume(entity); } catch (Exception e) { e.printStackTrace(); } } }

node.contents: I start a thread that does the polling at around 3 secs. I can send the messages from the main thread based on the polling results. The code works but keeps giving me the following two exceptions but keeps working in between.

astNode.text: I start a thread that does the polling at around 3 secs. I can send the messages from the main thread based on the polling results. The code works but keeps giving me the following two exceptions but keeps working in between.

elements.contents: java.lang.IllegalStateException: Invalid use of BasicClientConnManager: connection still allocated. Make sure to release the connection before allocating another one. org.apache.http.NoHttpResponseException: The target server failed to respond.

fragments.text: : connection still allocated. Make sure to release the connection before allocating another one.
: The target server failed to respond.

units.rawText: java.lang.IllegalStateException: Invalid use of BasicClientConnManager: connection still allocated. Make sure to release the connection before allocating another one. org.apache.http.NoHttpResponseException: The target server failed to respond.

node.contents: I could just mute the exceptions but I want to know what's going on. I was unable to find any solutions via Google. I've tried to consume content, make a new HttpPost object in the send method, stuff like that but nothing has helped so far.

astNode.text: I could just mute the exceptions but I want to know what's going on. I was unable to find any solutions via Google. I've tried to consume content, make a new HttpPost object in the send method, stuff like that but nothing has helped so far.

node.contents: What's a good strategy for a situation like this. I currently set the the keep-alive header in the HttpPost object in case that matters. Other than that I don't think there is anything I do. I think this has to do with the strategy overall. I don't want to make new object for every connection but I also don't know what level of reuse is recommended. Thanks for any help. Oh.. and this is HttpClient 4.2.2

astNode.text: What's a good strategy for a situation like this. I currently set the the keep-alive header in the HttpPost object in case that matters. Other than that I don't think there is anything I do. I think this has to do with the strategy overall. I don't want to make new object for every connection but I also don't know what level of reuse is recommended. Thanks for any help. Oh.. and this is HttpClient 4.2.2

node.contents: This might be overkill, but you might consider having a thread dedicated to http connection handing. This thread would spend sleep until it's time to poll or given a signal to send. The advantage to this is only one connection is ever used.

astNode.text: This might be overkill, but you might consider having a thread dedicated to http connection handing. This thread would spend sleep until it's time to poll or given a signal to send. The advantage to this is only one connection is ever used.

node.contents: These methods aren't synchronized and you're calling from different threads. Is it possible that your code might try to call send() while a poll() operation is ongoing? I imagine HttpClient won't like it if you try to make two requests at the same time using the same object.

astNode.text: These methods aren't synchronized and you're calling from different threads. Is it possible that your code might try to call send() while a poll() operation is ongoing? I imagine HttpClient won't like it if you try to make two requests at the same time using the same object.

node.contents: (If this is the problem, a trivial fix would be to add the synchronized keyword to both methods, assuming you don't mind blocking the threads that call them.)

astNode.text: (If this is the problem, a trivial fix would be to add the synchronized keyword to both methods, assuming you don't mind blocking the threads that call them.)

node.contents: I ended up using the code below. It works... have no idea why.

astNode.text: I ended up using the code below. It works... have no idea why.

elements.contents: DefaultHttpClient client = new DefaultHttpClient(); ClientConnectionManager mgr = client.getConnectionManager(); HttpParams params = client.getParams(); client = new DefaultHttpClient(new ThreadSafeClientConnManager(params, mgr.getSchemeRegistry()), params);

units.rawText: DefaultHttpClient client = new DefaultHttpClient(); ClientConnectionManager mgr = client.getConnectionManager(); HttpParams params = client.getParams(); client = new DefaultHttpClient(new ThreadSafeClientConnManager(params, mgr.getSchemeRegistry()), params);

node.contents: @Saad's answer was very helpful, but I've experienced delays when trying to load test single url with many concurrent requests.

astNode.text: @Saad's answer was very helpful, but I've experienced delays when trying to load test single url with many concurrent requests.

node.contents: Here is updated version that resolved the problem.

astNode.text: Here is updated version that resolved the problem.

elements.contents: DefaultHttpClient client = new DefaultHttpClient(); ClientConnectionManager mgr = client.getConnectionManager(); HttpParams params = client.getParams(); int maxConnections = 100; params.setParameter(ConnManagerPNames.MAX_CONNECTIONS_PER_ROUTE, new ConnPerRouteBean(maxConnections)); params.setIntParameter(ConnManagerPNames.MAX_TOTAL_CONNECTIONS, maxConnections); ThreadSafeClientConnManager conman = new ThreadSafeClientConnManager(params, mgr.getSchemeRegistry()); client = new DefaultHttpClient(conman, params);

units.rawText: DefaultHttpClient client = new DefaultHttpClient(); ClientConnectionManager mgr = client.getConnectionManager(); HttpParams params = client.getParams(); int maxConnections = 100; paramssetParameter(ConnManagerPNames.MAX_CONNECTIONS_PER_ROUTE, new ConnPerRouteBean(maxConnections)); paramssetIntParameter(ConnManagerPNames.MAX_TOTAL_CONNECTIONS, maxConnections); ThreadSafeClientConnManager conman = new ThreadSafeClientConnManager(params, mgr.getSchemeRegistry()); client = new DefaultHttpClient(conman, params);
